Author: Kimberlé Crenshaw
Thesis/Summary: Where at the age of 28, Crenshaw coins the term intersectionaity as a legal reform tatic to get at the cross-current oppressions faced by those with intersecting margiliazed idenities, specifically Black women in the context of court logic. She notes intersectinality as a "framework" in particular
Key concepts: Intersectionality, biopower, racical capitism, Objectvity, subjectivity

Author: Ian Haney López
Thesis/Summary: A histrical analysis of the contruction of race through legal reform / explores "racical fabrication"
Key concepts: Naturalization, Citizenship, construction of race and gender
Connections: Derrick Bell, Gerald Torres, Kathryn Milun, John Calmore, Patrick Buchanan, Barbara Flagg, Neil Gotanda

Author: Stuart Hall
Thesis/Summary: Representation is a shared system of codes, whose meaning is encoded. Nothing is outside of discourse
Key concepts: Power, Discourse, Connotative/ Denotative, Signification, Representation, Culture
Connections: an interpretation of Foucault, Different from Foucalt's discourse, Hall also refers to Saussure to focus on language
Intellectual movement: media study, but Hall goes into Marxism/ neo marxism, and cvritical race theory in his other writings

Author: Wendy Brown
Thesis/Summary: Is seen as time marking conflict within the larger academic community around the piloting theories on the future of women studies/ “feminist projects”
Connections: To Daniel Martinez HoSong, Lopez, and Crenshaw

Author: Siobahn Somerville
Thesis/Summary: The bifurcation of both race (black and white) and sexulaity (hetreo vs homo) in the late 19th century are deeply intertwinted
Key concepts: Critical Race Theory, binary systems, normativity
Connections: Stoler, Ferguson, Foucault, Nash
Intellectual movement: Race Theory, Sex Theory, Gender studies

Author: Eithne Luibhéid
Thesis/Summary: Border surveilled and controlled the immigrants within  its network.
Connections: Ann Laura Stoler, Foucault, Jasibur Puar, Robert S Chang, Kimberly Crenshaw, jacqueline Maria Hagan, Roger Rouse, Nina Glick Schiller, Linda Basch, and Cristina Szanton Blanc

Author: Ann Laura Stoler
Thesis/Summary: The introduction reintroduces Foucault's claim that sexuality was “originally, historically bourgeois" and reminds us that Foucault often had an elusive and suggestive treatment of race. This text will approach the way that colonial policies led to European distinctions of national character. It will also approach the study of comparative colonialisms and the underlying assumptions that serve the ability to compare. The author directly states their goal of drawing on Foucault’s insights to think about how the making of race has figured in placing sexuality at the center of imperial politics.
Connections: Edward Said, Michel Foucault
Intellectual movement: post colonial studies, foucauldian, Marxist theory

Author: Roderick Ferguson
Thesis/Summary: Racialized non-heteronormativity helps to articulate heteropatriarchy as universal.  Marx's silence on race, gender, and sexuality therefore reproduce the bourgeois' ideals of the universality of race, gender, and sexuality and their norms.
Connections: Muñoz, Althusser, Marx, Foucault, Grace Hong, Davis, Cedric Robinson, Robin DG Kelley, James Baldwin, Lorde, Fanon, Hazel Carby, Toni Morrison, Combahee River Collective, Foucault

Author: Sylvia Federici
Thesis/Summary: Federici intervenes in Marxist thought that a key, and overlooked, aspect of primitive accumulation and the transition from feudalism to capitalism in Western Europe was the accumulation and production of differences and through those differences hierarchy.  Federici is particularly interested in the production of new social meaning of woman that accompanied and laid the ground work for capitalism.  Women's labor in this period became devalued, excluded from the new capitalist markets, and figured as a communal, natural resource, a new commons in the wake of land enclosure.
Key concepts: Reproductive labor, gendered capitalism, primitive accumulation
Connections: Marx, Foucault (Biopower), Vandana Shiva, James C Scott

Work: Abolition democracy : beyond empire, prisons, and torture
Author: Angela Davis
Jasbir Puar
Geographic location: Rutgers University, New Brunswick, New Jersey, USA
Thesis/Summary: The racial construct of terrorist already carries sexual meaning.  The terrorist is a queer figure, a figure of deviant, aberrant sexuality.
Connections: Cites Ferguson "Aberrations in Black", Luibheid "Entry Denied", Butler, Spivak, Muñoz "Disidentifications", Said

Author: Maria Lugones
Thesis/Summary: Historical analysis of the colonical spanish oppression of Native populations through the lense of gender andsex construction
Connections: Marx, Foucalt, Crenshaw, Julie Greenberg, Paula Gunn Allen

Work: The Heart of Whiteness, The Search for Norma” and “The Birds and the Bees and the Making of Race”
Author: Julian Carter
Geographic location: California College of the Arts, California, USA
Thesis/Summary: Sex education was a technology for the homogenization of whiteness, using frankness alongside reticence about eroticism. Discourses set a norm used to police a community
Connections: Shapiro "Portrait", Josephine Robertson, Freud, Foucault, Garber, Hall, Sedgwick, Jacobson, Stoler, Butler

Author: Judith Butler
Thesis/Summary: The il/legibility of performativity dictates the bio-political categories that one falls into and thus the precarity one is exposed to.
Connections: Spivak, Arendt, Marx, Foucault

Author: Dean Spade
Thesis/Summary: Spade applies Foucault's concepts of disciplinary power and bio-power in his investigation of the working of oppression of trans people, concluding that both are inadequately addressed by legal reform, particularly legal reform focused on "what the law says about us".  These forms of power are both always racialized and classed, with bio-power in particular functioning through the production of an "us" whose lives are to be fostered and a "them" that are threats and drains.
Connections: Cites: Foucault "History of Sexuality Vol I", Spivak "Can the subaltern Speak?", Ann Laura Stoler "Race and the Education of Desire", Hartman, Ruth Wilson Gilmorew, Duggan "Twilight of Equality", Wendy Brown, Dylan Rodriguez, Susan Stryker, Davis, INCITE, Puar, Crenshaw "Mapping the Margins", Mitchell Dean

Author: Sarah Haley
Thesis/Summary: The violence of the carceral system of the emerging Jim Crow South in the post re-construction era solidified the construct of normative, white womanhood through the oppositional construction of the Black female as other, queer, and disposable.  Because violence did the work of the producing these norms, Black women's resistance to the carceral violence constituted contestations of the this construction of racialized gender.
Connections: Sara Ahmed, Butler "Bodies that Matter" 1993, Stephanie Camp, Hazel Carby, Cathy J Cohen, Patricia Hill Collins, Crenshaw, Davis, Du Bois, Duggan, Federici "Caliban and the Witch", Foucault "Hist. of Sexuality", Ruth Wilson Gilmore, Kali Gross, Stuart Hall, Hartman "Lose Your Mother", Higginbotham, Darlene Clark Hine, hooks, Tera Hunter "To Joy My Freedom", Mariame Kaba, Robin DG Kelley, Achille Mbembe, McClintock, Katherine McKittrick, Toni Morrison, Fred Moten, Muñoz, Cedric Robinson, Dylan Rodriguez, Assata Shakur, Siobhan Somerville "Queering the Color Line", Sontag, Spivak, Sterling, Mary Church Terrell, Alice Walker, Wynter

Author: Henry Giroux
Thesis/Summary: Giroux is interested in how biopolitics of disposability function through the neoliberal paradigm of austerity and privatization in the wake of Hurricane Katrina to enact selective violence on the Black population of New Orleans.
Connections: Agamben, Arendt, Davis, Mitchel Dean, Duggan, Achille Mbembe, Foucault

Connections: Cedric Robinson

Author: Daniel HoSang
Thesis/Summary: a review that summeraizes the cultural timeline of the word intersectionailty drawing from sources that date all the way back to the 1940s to present day where the term intersectinality can be drawn from/ influences shown. "usageas of the keyword call attention to the particular forms of analysis,solidarity, and collective action..."
Connections: Pauli Murray, Frances Beale, Combahee River Collective, K. Crenshaw, Wendey Brown, Judith butler

Author: Jennifer Nash
Thesis/Summary: Adds Black cultural theory into the conversation of gender studies as a scholarship as well as the cultural contexts/implications of the term intersectionality
Connections: WEB Du Bois, Paulette Caldwell, Roderick Ferguson, Hortense Spiller, Saidiya Hartman, Christina Sharpe, Sylvia Wynter
Intellectual movement: Black Feminist Theory, Culturtal Studies, Intersectionality

Author: Ruth Wilson Gilmore
Thesis/Summary: "Capitalism requires inequality and racism enshrines it"
